Memento Mori is a captivating video game that transports players into a mysterious world where life and death intertwine. Developed by a talented team of developers, this atmospheric adventure offers a unique blend of psychological horror and puzzle-solving gameplay. With its haunting visuals, thought-provoking narrative, and challenging puzzles, Memento Mori promises an unforgettable gaming experience.

Set in a gloomy and enigmatic city, Memento Mori delves into the dark realm of mortality and the human psyche. Players assume the role of a troubled protagonist who becomes entangled in a series of unexplainable events after encountering a cryptic artifact. The storyline explores themes of existentialism, the fragility of life, and the inevitable march towards death.

Memento Mori offers a mix of exploration, puzzle-solving, and occasional stealth elements. As you navigate the hauntingly beautiful environments, you'll encounter various obstacles and mysteries that must be solved to progress. The puzzles range from intricate riddles to intricate mechanisms, requiring you to think critically and pay attention to the smallest details. The game successfully strikes a balance between challenge and accessibility, providing a satisfying gameplay experience for both casual and hardcore gamers.

One of the standout features of Memento Mori is its atmospheric presentation. The game's graphics are exquisitely crafted, with a dark and melancholic aesthetic that perfectly complements the narrative. From eerie alleys to decaying mansions, every location feels meticulously designed to immerse players in a sense of foreboding. The haunting soundtrack further intensifies the atmosphere, ensuring that the game consistently delivers a spine-chilling experience.

The narrative of Memento Mori is masterfully crafted, unfolding gradually as you uncover secrets and interact with a cast of intriguing characters. The developers have skillfully woven a complex web of intrigue, keeping players engaged and invested in discovering the truth behind the protagonist's journey. Each character feels fleshed out, with their own motivations and secrets, adding depth to the overall storyline.

While Memento Mori may not offer multiple endings or branching paths, the game's replayability lies in its intricate puzzles and hidden secrets. Exploring every nook and cranny of the game world rewards players with additional insights, enhancing the overall experience. Additionally, the game's rich atmosphere and engrossing storyline make it worth revisiting to fully appreciate the nuances of the narrative.

Memento Mori is a hauntingly beautiful video game that successfully blends psychological horror, puzzle-solving, and immersive storytelling. With its gripping narrative, challenging puzzles, and atmospheric presentation, it stands as a testament to the power of indie game development. If you're a fan of atmospheric adventures that delve into existential themes and keep you on the edge of your seat, Memento Mori is an experience you won't want to miss. Prepare to confront your own mortality and immerse yourself in this captivating journey into the shadows.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106507444', 'num_games_owned': 337, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1641117981}
review:
This is not a bad game despite the bad reviews. People complained that the game begins with a character searching for her cell phone. I suppose they have never played a game that begins with a tutorial. The purpose of that scene was to familiarize players with how things work. Plenty of games do this. 

The story was actually really engaging. In fact it was probably the strongest part of the game. At times I found myself watching it like a movie. It gets a little ridiculous at the end with an unexpected twist. Because of the epilogue, the ending winds up being very unsatisfying. I guess they were trying to set up for the next game. They should have cut out the entire final chapter.

The biggest issue with this game is how slow everything moves. Not the story, but the actual game progression. Any time you click on something, a little video camera icon pops up and you have to wait a LONG time for the action to finish. There is no way to skip cut scenes or speed anything up, though you can right click to make dialogue go faster. Beyond that, it's not a bad game. Controls are standard for this kind of game and nothing too unusual. The inventory is annoying because it gets in the way of things. Some parts are tedious, but the number of locations is completely manageable and the puzzles are pretty straightforward. Not as bad as the reviews made it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198930212029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 780, 'last_played': 1600564737}
review:
Memento Mori is a hard game to thumbs up or down. For a budget title point and click it does many things exceptionally well, had details that most adventure games would skip, and you can tell the project was made with passion throughout. It's faults can range from charming to irritating. The game has great music, an interesting plot to start with that reaches it's peak half way but then becomes pretty dry and uninteresting towards the finale. The gameplay is sometimes fun but mostly tedious. 


GOOD
+ The soundtrack (also free download with this version), was really nice and moving. Cinematic strings accompanied by mellow piano pieces were nice on the ears. Though one or two pieces sound a bit 'midi like' for lack of a better word. I did have to turn music volume down quite a lot though!
+ Detailed environments from varying locations. Stylistic angles have that classic adventure game feel that you've probably come to know by now. Lots of things to interact with and dialogue for describing features around the world and items. I can appreciate a more chatty protagonist, it gives them more personality.

+ A surprising amount of single use animations for item interactions, sometimes can be a bit wonky but the game plays quite human. I like to see the characters eyes target an interactable, talk about it, and then grab it, even if it feels lengthy. It all adds immersion. Things moving in the environment background like cars driving by in Russia as just one example, make the world feel lived in.
+ I liked the contrast of different accents in the game. Voice acting ranges from good to subpar, but never bad. Lines are delivered convincingly and there is a lot of dialogue in the game. Lara, who works in France as a Russian Interpol agent was one of the better characters, she was a bit quirky and funny.

+ It may be an endearing quality but I liked the busywork you do reading emails, writing emails, making phonecalls etc. These features are also quite detailed, you get alot of information that at first is a bit overwhelming. It felt pretty grounded and human.



BAD
- The basic main plot of the game is based around a criminal underworld of art theft, forgeries, and cults. For the first half of the game there is rarely any sense of urgency. You spend a hell of a lot of time doing uninteresting day to day tasks such as finding a plug socket for your phone to charge the battery, and finding water to fill a jug, heat on a stove with firewood to warm up and wash your face. These things only felt like filler and made the game feel longer when I wanted to advance the story.
- The story didn't draw me in or interest me. I must admit, a murder mystery is usually more my style but the premise is set up well here with the focus on art theft. Unfortunately it's cluttered and confusing. Often times it felt like dialogue sequences contradicted each other. Around the 60% mark into the game I think I tuned out and it was hard to get re-immersed from then on. A twist involving two characters comes towards the later half of the game, and although I enjoyed the sequence of events leading up to it, the reveal felt rather flat and out of nowhere and from then on it just gets crazier. 

- Graphical oddities such as the BEAMING GOD RAYS that emanate from any light source in the game. A simple light bulb looks like staring into the sun.
- Audible oddities such as dialogue sometimes features reverb to emphasise a rooms open space. Which is great if done right, but it sounds so robotic here And worse so, the reverb effect cuts out immediately after dialogue ends.

- The overlay for item menu very often would pop down and get in the way of my cursor when wanting to leave an area.
- Our lead protagonist Max. A french professor who got caught up in the crime world to pay off hospital bills has a good premise to build the character and should make him likeable despite the bad things he's done. But that being said he is very boring. Max has zero personality and every scene you play as him feels like a drag. This is surprising as Lara the character you start the game as feels much more likeable and relatable.

- Puzzles in the game are predictable and easy. The real difficulty comes from knowing what to do and where to go.
- Despite the context of the situation, the character always speaks out loud, this is hilarious when you're supposed to be keeping a low profile.
- Mechanics such as the 'respond positively/negatively or questionably' was shallow and felt ultimately meaningless. You haven't any idea how you're going to react and if you get it wrong there's no downsides.


Overall I believe that Memento Mori isn't a very fulfilling or memorable experience. I think a lot of heart went into creating it and there's a lot of detail and information to delve into which I wasn't expecting going in. but where it ultimately falls flat is the story. For me personally it wasn't done in a very consistent or appealing manner. A lot of great ideas are thrown into a mix and not all of those ideas are well incorporated in the end result. The gameplay, although very easy to pick up, was meandaring for the most part and littered with chores to keep the player busy for as long as possible. It was okay based on getting it very cheap on sale though, and I hope MM2 can focus on what made the first game decent and fine tune it into something more polished.




5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198140435102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 791, 'last_played': 1510695456}
review:
Special game to me. First of all, it was bugged so I had to ask some technical help on forum and developer who were only partly helpful and I was able to finish game despite that game crashed in halfway through when I was playing in Czech language. English dubbing did not work for me at all, only subtitles. Czech language dubbing causes crash and sometimes ruins immersion.

Animations are sometimes glitchy but overally look good. Graphics decent and dialogues are somehow suitable for the atmosphere.

Czech dubbing is another problem. Actors read text like they do not know what is the clue in game. Example, orator says Spain instead of Portugal, like it does not matter - those are different countries.

There is NPC in the room, you can talk to, you save game, resume game and he disappears. One time, someone called, I pressed ESC because I wanted to save and Lara did not even have chance to take it.

There is for some a kind of annonying part where your characters use e-mail and phone relatively often but it does not ruin immersion, only complicates it for players and gives us players feeling how desperate might the characters sometimes feel.

You can not skip some animations and so will annoy you running back and forth for clues. But skipping with double click to another location works fine in most cases.

There are quite a lot of locations for such short adventure and camera is zoomed out so you see most of room but I missed some "hidden" items to look at or pick up, just because they were tiny and on the edge of screen. Clearly, it was intention but as you mostly use TAB to your adventage as it shows items you can interact with, it does not show ALL of them. At least it helps.

Sometimes game shows you what your character is doing with zoomed window that is from different angle but is sometimes glitched when it merges with the background.

You will play as Lara seperately and Max seperately doing their own adventures under command of Ostankovic who pushes them to take risk and go look further for clues of lost "quest" things. Public can not know about the loss, so everything you do with Lara and Max is secret and you will have to stay undercover and be careful what you do, cause it matters in the END. Though at first, you have no clue what is to come, maybe another replay would change things, as there are 8 different endings.

There were two puzzles which did not make sense to me and I only had to use walkthrough, I would probably have to use many combinations to get the right answer. It was more about mindset, understanding what the legend says rather than what was most obvious or logical answer. I can not say it is bad, I was surprised by how badly I was looking for a solution.

It has nice cutscenes which really add value of drama to the game. Game has nice plot twist by the end of it.

I saw problems in this game since first minute, it could be polished better, but as the story enveloped, I enjoyed it, and game gives you minor clues about the upcoming plot twist.

It is clearly not so great, but I like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 2363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1528636179}
review:
Memento Mori is a great classic point and click adventure with mostly easy difficulty, excellent writing, good graphics which scale rather nicely to 4k, a captivating soundtrack and only falls flat on a few ends by featuring absolutely horrible voice acting as well as very stiff animations.

The downsides are more than made up by the great story though, which progresses at a steady yet sometimes maybe slightly too slow pace.

It feels neither too long nor too short and has a quite interesting finale with quite a few unforeseeable plot twists.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028018534', 'num_games_owned': 1330, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1453119139}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=84jEsLSe91Y

Memento Mori ‚Äì remember that you can die. This is the medieval Latin theory and practice of reflection on mortality, especially as a means of considering the vanity of earthly life and the transient nature of all earthly goods and pursuits. It is related to the ars moriendi ("The Art of Dying") and related literature. Memento Mori has been an important part of ascetic disciplines as a means of perfecting the character, by cultivating detachment and other virtues, and turning the attention towards the immortality of the soul and the afterlife. This is taken from Wikipedia and it's essential for part of the game.

This game have a lot of options. The game is highly scalable ‚Äì resolution, monitor frequency, V-sync, AA, shader quality, texture filtering, mipmaping, dynamic shadows and reflections. But when I put everything on high the framerate tanks. I have decent PC and this shouldn't happen, the game is from 2008. Also there are a lot of audio options and even if you want your cursor can be animated or not, which is a neat little feature.

In the game you control two characters. The first is Larisa Svetlova ‚Äì ex-police officer in Russia, now working for Interpol. The second and the main character here is Maxim Durrand. He use to forge painting and sell, until he got caught by Larisa. Instead sending him to jail, he agree to become informant for the russian police. Both Max and Lara are drag in investigation by Colonel Ostankovich. There was an alarm failure in Hermitage museum in Saint Petersburg and Ostankovich that something happens. He force Lara to send Max to see if it's missing something in the museum. Of course there is ‚Äì few paintings From here on their own they travel to Lisbon, Lyon, residence in Scotland and even in Finland in search for the missing paintings. Their journey is acompanied by mysterious deaths, secret signs, interrogating suspects and solving puzzles. The story is good, but not great. It starts slow and took a few hours to get interesteing and for a adventure game this is not great. I don't want to spoil anything, but the last act throws a lot on you, that wasn't hinted throughout the game that this maybe how it will end. This is good and bad. Just it came from nowhere. The game wraps up really well. It was enjoyble, connects all the little hints, that you see, but from which you can't piece the ending before you see it. It's hard to explain without ruining the end, so trust me on this one. I just wish the story wasn't dragging so much in the beginning.

For an adventure game the most important things for me are story and puzzles. I already cover the story. As for the puzzles I can say they are not hard. I was stuck briefly on one or two. All of them have common sense ‚Äì pick up this, put it there, combine objects, look at some inside your inventory or around you. I didn't find any obscure or illogical. Some of them are quite unique. They are 3D puzzles. What I mean is you look an object and you can rotate the camera around it in 360 degrees. I like them, but they are few and far between.

You have a conversation system with 3 type of answers most of the time, but what will a character say when you choose ‚Äúpositively‚Äù, ‚Äúnegatively‚Äù or ‚Äúquestionably‚Äù, you can't really tell. Most of the times they will say things that doesn't sound like what you choose.

The graphics are alright. Here all backgrounds are 3D, not pre-render like older adventure games and they look great. But some characters model doesn't look that good, like Maxs for example. And NPC's also suffer with the lack of enough polish.

Also the character movement is not good. It looks cluncky. It's like the game didn't came out in 2008.

The level design is really great. I like all the places you visit and they have a lot of detail put in them. There almost always things that can be clicked just for the character to say something and they are not essential for the story and puzzles. It's great to have a minor thing like that. It's about the atmosphere. Even something like Lara's office looks nice and have enough background details to feel like a real place. 

For me the worst part here is the sound design, especually the voice acting. It's bad. It's not unbearably bad, but still. The only one I like is the narrator. Lara and Max suppose to have accents, but the feel forced and the line delivery is not great. At one scene Max is supose to be angry, but it's so badly played and I just cringe. This ruin the moment.

As for the music I can't point a single track. It's not bad, it's just nothing special, nothing to remember. Most of them include a piano, but the melodies feels like i've heard them before in movies and games. There are occasional deep male vocals accompanied by orchestra, but non of the tracks contribute that much for the atmosphere.

The sound effects are are really good. Things like walking, moving an object, hitting crushing and envoirmental sounds and feel proper. I wish the music and voice acting were on the same level.

There are quite number of issues I have with the game, mostly are minor things, but nonetheless they drag the game down. Cutscene. They don''t look good. They are blurry, like you have something on the screen. Character movement. When you make Lara or Max take something, for example, it take them ages to do it and it's frustrating. Speaking. When character observe something, he is saying out loud. Sometimes it's important and an NPC shouldn't hear it. It's bizzare. Lip sync. It's bad and you can even barely seen the mouths moving. Camera. A lot of times obstruct my view and I wonder around trying to figure out what am I supose to do. And in cutscenes often is badly placed and heads are cutoff. Lara. She is not an interestig character. I didn't care for her like I care about Max. Some are minor issues, but when you combine with the pacing of the story and bad voice acting, you see why the game is dragged down.

I consider Memento Mori decent adventure game. As a whole the game won't be stuck in my mind, but the ending will be. It have great locations, good plot, not-so-hard puzzles and few endings, but pacing, bad voice acting and other little issues drag the game down. I recommend it, but on deep sale.

Das Spiel macht auf mich einen durchschnittlichen Eindruck. Der Versuch, auf der kleinen Welle neuer Adventures in den 2000er Jahren mitzuschwimmen, ohne das Spiel richtig fertiggestellt zu haben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198177942134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1444189931}
review:
I really, really wanted to like this game. I've been a fan of adventure point and click games since their heyday in the 90s. It does have some good elements and some that are lacking. For the short version; if it's on sale and you need something to do for the next 10 hours, get it. If you're expecting a great adventure game on the scale of Longest Journey or Syberia, you're in for a big letdown. I'm only going to select the "yes" for recommending this game because I don't want this genre to die. I want more developers to create more adventure games!

Pros:
****The characters' voices all have appropriate regional accents. The French character of Max has a French accent and the Russian character of Lara has a charming Russian accent. Points for authenticity!
****Like most adventure games, there are puzzles and they all fit into the context of the game and had logical answers. Some may have been a little too easy while others required a bit too much pixel hunting. All in all though, the puzzles were good.
****Nice graphics and scenery design. I'm a digital artist so I always appreciate great graphics and well rendered 3D models. Some character animations were used time and again but I came to see them as just character quirks rather than the developer recycling animations. 
****The game took about 10 hours for me to complete and I only had to check a walk-through once because I missed clicking on something in a scene. Since I bought this game when is was about $3, I'd say I made a fantastic investment. 

Cons
****The story doesn't really make any sense and by the time you get to the ending you will have a feeling of  WTF?! Even though they had the character explain the entire story and why everything happened at the end of the game (it was a worse "entire plot explanation" than you'd find in one of the old Sean Connery James Bond movies), it still made no sense to me at all. You know what people say about the ending of Lost? This ending tops that. I understand what they were saying but, logically, it makes no sense to me.
****The "multiple endings" thing is a joke. If you don't do something in a few scenes then you get a different voice-over epilogue. That's it. I was quite disappointed by that. I love games were my choices matter but this had nothing to do with choice and everything to do with just crossing all the T's and dotting the I's. 

So yeah, technically good but story-wise it's confusing and forgettable. Like I said, if it goes on sale again at a cheap price then pick it up for a great time-killer. If you're expecting a great adventure game where your choices actually matter and there is a fantastic story, go look up Dreamfall Chapters.

review:
When playing through this game I could only help but think about what Stephen King said about Kubrick's film "The Shining." He said that it was like a fancy car without an engine. That is exactly what Memento Mori is like. It may look great, but it just can't do that much. The look of the game is really great. The beginning is very promising with a dead scientist surfacing and it is apparent that you will be involved in finding out why and how he died and your first task in this point and click adventure is to get dressed and find your cell phone so you can charge it. I'm dead serious. The game is full of mundane tasks like this. Point and clicks are usually known for their puzzles and their stories. The puzzles are pretty lacking, and even when you do get a puzzle, they aren't that difficult. There are more mundane tasks then puzzles in this game. 
Well, if the story is great it doesn't matter about the lack of puzzles right? Well....The story isn't bad. I've ready other reviews saying that this is a story driven game that pushes you to keep playing. I beg to differ. I felt that the story was nothing really special. Honestly, this game was a chore to play, due to the lack of brainpower this game required and the cast of characters. On the whole, the performances are hit and miss. Sometimes the voice acting is great, and other times you can almost visualise the actor in the booth with the script in front of him. What also drives me crazy is that while you may hear anger or frustration in the characters voice, the body language and facial expressions of the character do not convey any of this emotion. It's very easy to separate the voice from the character, and that is annoying. This game has also been praised for its ending. Depending on what you do and say throughout the game (Mass Effect even affected point and click games) you will get one of six endings. The problem that I see with the ending is that it feels disjointed from the rest of the game. The focus of the ending is entirely different from the rest of the game, which can really throw you off. 
Now to the only good point, the look of the game. It is great to look at. The cinematics are fitting and the places you get to visit are beautifully rendered. Every action has an animation. A lot of work went into the graphic design and it is the only solid gold star I can give this game. 
Hopefully, Memento Mori 2 will be less of a disapppointment. I bought the Memento Mori Bundle for 7.99. Memento More 2 will have to be incredible for me to believe that buying these games is worth suffering through the first one.

I decided to go 'negative' for my review on this game mostly because of its price. I enjoyed it but the number of flaws it has makes ¬£9.99 too expensive. If I had to rate it I would give it 5/10. If you want to buy it, wait for a sale and I'd recommend you spend a maximum of ¬£5 for it.

The reason I give this game a mediocre score is that everything else is lack-lustre. The visuals are adequate, the background music ia a bit poor and the voice acting highly variable.The interface takes a little while to get used to. You have an iicon that appears over a useable object that should display what right click and left click will do but this icon is really hard to see.

Conversations feel forced and too drawn out. Sometimes it is even difficult to figure out what a character is trying to say because the wording is so weird and unnatural.

If you like story-rich point and clicks, wait for a sale and get this. Otherwise don't bother.

review: Stilted dialog, pixel-hunting, and counter-intuitive puzzles make this an example of what's wrong with modern-day point-and-clicks.  None of this is as bad as the awful dialog system, however, in which you are typically presented with 3 different responses: positive, negative, and curious.  The problem is that the game doesn't bother to tell you the specifics of what your character will say when you pick one of these--you just have to pick the attitude that most closely matches what you WANT to say and hope that that's what the game designers had in mind as well.  The story probably would have been interesting if not for the badly written and poorly voice-acted dialog.  Can't recommend this one.
